newsitem.title: USA: USDA wants to remove Italy from swine fever list.
newsitem.headline: USDA wants to remove Italy from swine fever list.

text.p: The Agriculture Department said it proposed to declare most of Italy free of African swine fever because there have been no confirmed outbreaks since 1983.

The island of Sardinia would remain on the list of places suspected of having the disease, the USDA said in a notice published in the Federal Register. The agency said it would review public comments received by August 11 on the proposed change.
Declaring most of Italy free of the disease would relieve certain restrictions on the importation into the United States of pork and pork products from all regions of Italy.

"Because hog cholera and swine vesicular disease exist in Italy, and because Italy, as a member state of the European Union, has certain trade practices regarding live swine and pork and pork products that are less restrictive than are acceptable to the United States, the importation into the United States of live swine and pork and pork products from Italy would continue to be subject to certain restrictions," the USDA said.
